We never get bored of his bike tricks  &ldquoI finally made it to Graub&uumlnden, says Danny MacAskill in his most recent film as he poses on his bike on the top of the Swiss mountain, before catapulting off on one of his high-adrenalin rides. In the film, sponsored by Red Bull, it&rsquos still the same old Danny, only the mountains are higher, the budgets are bigger, and, well, it&rsquos hard for him ever to top the feeling that he gave us when he did his first street trials video back in 2009, or the romance he delivered when he cycled The Ridge.  But nevertheless, the boy from Dunvegan, Isle of Skye, still knows how to move us &ndash and he&rsquos always bringing us something new. He did so earlier this, in spite of a recent broken knee cap, when he performed in the Celtic Connections music and bike spectacular Bothy Culture And Beyond.  &ldquoI suppose when you first jump on your bike it&rsquos your first dose of freedom, he said in a recent film about his Kilimanjaro bike trip. &ldquoYou can constantly think of something new to challenge yourself and it&rsquos kind of like a game that you&rsquoll never get bored of.  28 Anna Meredith  Composer, 40  Why? She took the Edinburgh International Festival by storm  Bright, breezy and pleasantly down to earth isn&rsquot how you&rsquod imagine a composer of left field music to be &ndash this, after all, is the woman who wrote a concerto for beatboxer and orchestra, and another piece to be performed using &ldquobody percussion by a flash mob at the M6 services.  But the description fits Anna Meredith perfectly. A 10-year veteran of commissions for the BBC Proms and a winner of the Scottish Album Of The Year for Varmints, her debut record, the Scot&rsquos playful but intellectually rigorous compositions had already won her a legion of admirers before this year&rsquos Edinburgh Festival.  After it, she was the name on everyone&rsquos lips thanks to having had not one but three separate works performed in the capital, including an orchestrated  performance of Varmints as part of the uber-cool Light On The Shore series at the Leith Theatre.  27 Robbie Grfith  Freerunner, 17  Why? He delivers his parkour thrills Renton-style  &ldquoChoose le. Choose a sport. Choose an interest. These were the words which kicked off a viral video, a parkour remake of the classic Trainspotting scene, in which Coatbridge-lad, Grfith flipped and hurtled across Edinburgh, until it concluded with the alternative line, &ldquoChoose parkour.  The film, Grfith recalls, was triggered when his brother suggested that he should make a video to the Trainspotting track and his dad then suggested they should go one further and remake the scene. Grfith and a film-maker friend made it, uploaded it in March last year, and overnight became a sensation. Since then Grfith has travelled the world with parkour, competing, visiting friends, doing a six month tour of America with his sponsor, the Motus Projects, and yes making more videos.  26 Mhairi Black  SNP MP, 24  Why? She won&rsquot be told, on anything  One of the coolest things about Mhairi Black is the way that three years at Westminster doesn&rsquot seem to have changed her very much at all. Yes, she&rsquos got a little older &ndash she went in at just 20 years old &ndash but she hasn&rsquot got any quieter or less determined. When, as she has said, Alex Salmond suggested to her that she should have a bit of a makeover and some new clothes, she ignored the advice. When online haters took her to pieces she shrugged them off, and then fought back &ndash with a powerful speech earlier this year describing some of the misogynistic and homophobic comments she received.  Mhairi Black is who she is &ndash gay, smart, passionate, angry, socialist &ndash and she&rsquos not changing any of that for anyone. She even still maintains her disregard for the institution which she is part of and, just last month, reiterated her feelings. &ldquoIt does not serve us, she said, &ldquoand in actual fact I would go so far as to say it&rsquos not even a parliament it&rsquos a club that masquerades itself.  25 Katie Archibald  Cyclist, 24  Why? She&rsquos got style and medals  Katie Archibald is nothing  not colourful. Her hair has been just about every hue under the sun. Her left arm is tattooed by drawings from The Thinker of Tender Thoughts by the poet Shel Silverstein. On her right are the Olympic rings. Her love of motorbikes saw her crash at 70mph on a Cheshire lane in the run up to the Rio Olympics.  But in between all this colour and extracurricular drama, there are the races and that really cool thing she does which is to win medals &ndash three at this year&rsquos Commonwealth Games and she has her eyes on three, too, at the next Olympics in Tokyo 2020.  24 Bigg Taj  Beatboxer, 35  Why? His mouth is a drum machine  As a kid Bigg Taj started doing beatbox long before he knew what those sounds he was making were. Then, he says, &ldquowhen I heard guys like Killa Kela, Rahzel and Scratch, I realised what it is and decided to pursue it. It&rsquos been my passion for well over a decade, creating music with my mouth and pushing the boundaries of my vocals.  Now Scotland&rsquos premier beatboxer, Bigg Taj, a Sikh of Indian heritage, has performed with his idols, supporting Method Man and Redman. But Bigg Taj isn&rsquot just about the performance &ndash he also runs a Youtube channel with beatbox tutorials and has been doing youth work for years. The workshops, he says, are about the creative writing and beatboxing, but they&rsquore also about giving young people a space to talk. Among these, he says, is one in Polmont prison with rap emcee Spee Six Nine.  23 Claire Cunningham  Dancer, 41  Why? She alters the way we look at bodies, able or disabled  Dancer and choreographer Claire Cunningham&rsquos extraordinary shows have always challenged how people feel about disability. When she dances on crutches &ndash which she has used to walk since the age of fourteen &ndash they become marvellous, magical and sometimes humorous extensions of herself. Her shows ask big questions. Guide Gods, for instance, looked at religious attitudes towards the disabled. Give Me a Reason to Live was based on the depiction of disability in the work of the painter Hieronymus Bosch. It was, she said, a live memorial to the disabled victims of the Nazi euthanasia program.  Cunningham was born with osteoporosis and arthrogryposis, but didn&rsquot view herself as disabled until she went to university. Only later, when she came in contact with the choreographer Jess Curtis, did she realise that she might be able to dance, and that she had her own very special set of tools, her crutches.  Her most recent work, The Way You Look  Tonight is a collaboration with Curtis.  22 Richard Madden  Actor, 32  Why? Two words. The Bodyguard.  Richard Madden, without a doubt, is having his own special cool moment right now. It&rsquos happening for him. The Bodyguard, in which he stars as Sergeant David Budd, is, according to the BBC, their &ldquodrama of the decade.  At the bookies, the odds on him being the next Bond just got slashed to 10/1. He&rsquos having to worry about being objectied and being seen as a hunk.  You can&rsquot open a newspaper without coming across some article about who he is dating &ndash actor Ellie Bamber &ndash or what his latest movements have been. But, one of the coolest things about the Renfrewshire born actor, whose biggest role, previous to this was Robb Stark in Game Of Thrones, is that he clearly acknowledges he hasn&rsquot always been cool. In one interview he confessed that  he weren&rsquot acting he&rsquod be a &ldquoshy, fat kid living in Scotland with no girlfriend.  21 Shirley Manson  Singer, 52  Why? She&rsquos not going to be owned by anyone  &ldquoI actually feel that this is the most glorious part of my career, Manson said earlier this year. And it is, on many levels &ndash not just because her band, Garbage, have stuck together for over twenty years, but because she&rsquos being more outspoken, almost, now more than ever and she is showing younger artists the way to go. She has spoken out on #MeToo.  Earlier this year she wrote a moving op-ed in the New York Times about her experience of self harm. &ldquoI didn&rsquot know I was a cutter until the first time I chose to cut, she wrote. &ldquoI didn&rsquot even know it was a &lsquothing.&rsquo..  Last month she had a go at the mainstream music industry, calling it &ldquoexploitative. Along with Chvrches frontwoman, Lauren Mayberry, she is set to deliver the keynote speech at the annual South by Southwest conference next year &ndash and you can bet it will be fizzing with feminism.  But above all, it&rsquos glorious because of the raw power she still has a performer. Garbage performed at the Barrowlands earlier this month, and Peter Ross, reviewing the gig for The Times observed, &ldquoShe was amped, vamped, pumped veins made a river delta on her temples.

title: fife-beach-off-limits-after-sewage-leak
story: A pollution warning was issued for Leven Beach which urged people to also stay away from the River Leven.  There was a power outage at Levenmouth waste water treatment works on Thursday, which caused the sewage leak.  People have been advised not to swim or paddle at Leven Beach. Dog owners have been urged not to walk their pets at the beach or near the river.  The fault has now been repaired but the potential risk will remain over the weekend.

title: future-shock-why-the-haunting-of-coronation-street-is-genuinely-disturbing
story: Personally, I take comfort in Corinthians 15:52: &ldquoThe trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall be raised incorruptible. Perhaps it&rsquos not entirely coincidental that Corrie&rsquos theme is played on the trumpet, and the programme itself filled with the undead likes of Ken, Rita and Audrey &ndash who only look alive thanks to their suspiciously buoyant barnets.  Yet, it&rsquos not Corrie that has fulfilled the Biblical prophecy of eternal le. It was actually the soap&rsquos ad break &ndash with strong evidence for resurrection arriving in the unexpected form of Egon from the Ghostbusters punting credit cards. It&rsquos odd Paul the Apostle failed to mention such specics.  If you haven&rsquot seen it yet, this posthumous turn by the late, great actor Harold Ramis blasphemously condenses the classic 80s movie into a 30-second ode to Halax&rsquos interest rates. Bill Murray is conspicuous by his absence &ndash clearly thinking better of the whole queasy concept. He is, however, replaced by special effects jiggery pokery with some banker called &ldquoGreg, a cuddly everyman who busts a few ghosts using the power of his flexible friend. &lsquoBusters fans should note this is all strictly non-canon.  The grand irony is that Ramis did not even have the choice to appear alongside &ldquoGreg killing the undead &ndash by the virtue of being dead himself. If he&rsquod ed as an actual ghost, perhaps biting Dan Ackroyd&rsquos head off for selling him out, it may have injected some imagination into Halax&rsquos morally bankrupt concept. The dead may be rising, but they are certainly not incorruptible.  Boo the Kehoe  NOT everyone thinks the new Ghostbusters ad campaign is deeply distasteful and indicative of a creatively barren culture gnawing at itself and choking on the vomit.  Catherine Kehoe, Halax&rsquos managing director for brands and marketing, thinks bustin&rsquo the deceased with a nuclear-powered laser gun creates wonderful synergy with the bank&rsquos core brand values. Perhaps because no-one seems to have told her Ramis is dead.  &ldquoAs a straightforward bank, we keep things simple, she enthused. &ldquo seeing Greg show Dan Ackroyd and Harold Ramis just how easy it is for our current account customers to pay with Visa contactless. Doubt Ramis is much bothered, to be honest. I suspect Ackroyd will now have a bit of spare cash to spend, however. Kehoe&rsquos nauseating quote could easily serve as a farewell-cruel-world note and even your children would understand why you did it.  The agency behind this unholy abomination, Adam&ampEve/DBB, are not naive hucksters &ndash having previously superimposed Halax&rsquos rotund everyman Greg into The Wizard of Oz, Top Cat and other beloved pop culture creations which reside deep within the collective subconscious psyche.  Clearly, no cherished iconography is sacred when making cold corporate brands synonymous with warm childhood memories. Perhaps &ldquoGreg will be dropped into Titanic next to sell travel insurance.  All is illusion  AT least it&rsquos real Ghostbusters footage that Halax&rsquos gormless patsy &ldquoGreg now pollutes. Soon, such time-consuming CGI hoo-ha will seem very quaint indeed. In the very near future, not only Ramis but all dead actors will live forever in new movies. You might too &ndash perhaps appearing in footage of an unsavoury event you have no memory of partaking in. That&rsquos because you didn&rsquot and it&rsquos being used to blackmail you. Welcome to the terrying reality of &ldquoDeepFakes.  In December last year, an anonymous internet user going by the name DeepFakes posted some realistic looking &ldquoadult clips of famous folk on messageboard Reddit. He created these films utilising a sophisticated AI program to insert celebrities&rsquo faces onto the bodies of pornographic film stars. One year on, this software is out there and anyone can use it &ndash with the results growing more convincing by the day. Remember, Space Invaders was indistinguishable from magic just a few decades ago.  DeepFakes software essentially offers users the ability to convincingly swap one face for another in any image or video. Movies such as Gladiator &ndash where Ollie Reed&rsquos long-overdue death meant his head had to be superimposed digitally upon a body double &ndash required skilled CGI experts spending months to get convincing results. A somewhat fitting final curtain call from Ollie, who spent most of his le off his head anyway.  Now though, even Ollie in his most inebriated state could manage to feed a selfie into an algorithm and produce a high quality face swap.&nbspAnd since so many of us have our gurning coupons plastered over the internet, we can all expect to be starring in a movie of our own very soon &ndash indistinguishable from reality and fresh for social embarrassment, bullying or blackmail.  Once you retreat from reality in shame, don&rsquot worry &ndash you&rsquoll be able to entertain yourself by imposing your face onto Indiana Jones or Rocky movies. If this doesn&rsquot appeal, you can always bring about WW3 by propagating some fake news. On the downside, Putin may soon release footage of a certain alleged hotel room encounter with a certain President, who will now be able to claim it&rsquos a DeepFake. And in this world where no court of law can distinguish between real footage and digital fabrication, R Kelly will be a very happy man.  And finally...  DON&rsquoT despair of a future where it&rsquos impossible to distinguish illusion from reality &ndash take heart in the fact the young Leia, Luke and Han will be reborn digitally in countless new Star Wars movies  to consume ravenously for thousands of years to come.  Ironically, geneticists will likely have created real Ewoks by then, and will perhaps be the only flesh and blood creatures left in this immortal franchise. Perhaps we&rsquoll also once again get to fawn over the steely-eyed, chiselled beauty of the young Steven Seagal &ndash getting back to kicking Russian gangster ass instead of just kissing it.  Buoyed by hopes of movie stardom, most young actors are currently signing away the rights to their image for the next million years like a Scientology contract.  Yet, they&rsquore superfluous to requirements. All film studios need now is a selfie and an answerphone message. Troublesome and expensive flesh embodiment of talent will be disposed of. The profession of acting will have as much prospects as journalism in the forthcoming post-truth world, a cosy,familiar prison where we now have all the stars &ndash and facts &ndash we&rsquoll ever need.

title: theresa-may-admits-to-getting-irritated-by-leadership-talk
story: The Prime Minister insisted she was focused on the country's future rather than her own, in a BBC interview to mark the six-month countdown to Brexit.  Mrs May criticised Mr Johnson for using "completely inappropriate" language when he described her Brexit strategy as putting the UK in a "suicide vest".  Around 50 Brexiteers met to war-game ways to oust the PM last Tuesday evening and Mr Johnson is widely-expected to vie to replace Mrs May.  Asked  she would reassure the Conservative Party she was not determined to go on and on, the PM told BBC Panorama's Inside No 10: Deal or No Deal?: "I get a little bit irritated but this debate is not about my future, this debate is about the future of the people of the UK and the future of the United Kingdom.  "That's what I'm focused on and that's what we should all be focused on.  "It's ensuring that we get that good deal from the European Union which is good for people in the UK, wherever they live in the UK, that's what's important for us ... It's the future of people in the UK that matters."  Mr Johnson faced a Tory backlash after comparing Mrs May's Brexit plan to a "suicide vest" and his former communications director, Guto Harri, said on Saturday that his ex-boss was "digging his political grave".  Mrs May said the former Foreign Secretary's comments were "not right".  She went on: "I have to say that that choice of language is completely inappropriate.  "I was Home Secretary for six years and, as Prime Minister for two years now using language like that was not right and it's not language I would have used."  The PM was once described as "bloody dficult woman" by former Cabinet minister Ken Clarke, and later claimed the description as a badge of honour.  She told the programme that person was "still there" but there was a &ldquodference between those who think you can only be bloody dficult in public and those who think actually you bide your time, and you're bloody dficult when the time is right and when it really matters."

title: a-good-week-for-the-eu-with-its-stance-on-hungary
story: Prime Minister Victor Orb&aacuten of the ruling Hungarian Fidesz party came to Strasbourg to debate the criticisms in a resolution drawn up by Dutch MEP and my group colleague Judith Sargentini. If anyone needs a refresher it is worth remembering this is a man who has called migrants poison, referred to &lsquomuslim invaders&rsquo and peddled anti-Semitic myths about George Soros. His government, democratically elected it has to be said, has forcibly retired judges, banned international NGOs from working in Hungary, built a fence to keep out refugees and lots more besides.  As one academic succinctly put it this week &ldquothe EU is like a club with a strong bouncer, but little security once you&rsquore inside the venue. The present Hungarian government has not been abiding by the values that make up the EU, and the EU, slowly, had got round to acting. The Parliament, for the first time ever, was to debate the triggering of Article 7 proceedings, effectively putting Hungary in a sin bin cutting funding, limiting voting rights and other measures until it plays by the rules.  On the day he simply fell back on tired rhetoric asserting that the report &ldquoinsults the honour of the Hungarian nation whilst feeding a victim complex that the Parliament had already made up its mind. He fell back on anti-immigration rhetoric repeatedly talking about migrants whilst ignoring all other criticisms proudly proclaiming that &ldquothe Hungarian people have decided not to be a nation of migrants.  Remember, Hungary signed up to the values of the EU when it joined and these values are part of the organisation. These include the rights of iniduals and the EU institutions must defend them where possible, particularly in the face of the threats we now face. Europe is a continent of migrants and  our history shows us anything it is that narrow minded anti-immigrant rhetoric always ends badly.  Unsurprisingly his speech fell flat. MEPs from the centre right EPP, the centre left S&ampD, the liberal ALDE and Green groups all stood one by one to condemn his government&rsquos actions and at the end of the day with 448 votes in favour the European Parliament voted to recommend the initiation of Article 7 proceedings. This is a real strong sign that EU values must be respected and could result in Hungary being stripped of its right to vote in the Council of the European Union.  The details of the resolution that we approved are grim reading. The Budgetary Control Committee recommends deduction of EU funding to Hungary over concerns that much of it ends up in the pockets of his cronies the Culture Committee condemns attacks on academic freedom the Constitutional Affairs Committee condemns infringement of judicial independence the Committee on Women&rsquos Rights condemns reversals on gender equality.  This week&rsquos debate got to the heart of what the EU is for. To what extent should the sovereign EU states be able to pick and choose from the common rules they all voluntarily signed up to? To what extent should the rest of us be able to call them on it? Can solidarity be imposed?  None of these have simple answer, and in the EU everything is connected to everything else, that&rsquos the point. Recently, in Greece a profligate series of Greek governments tipped their economy into chaos, and it was only EU support that avoided a worse disaster. But could, should, the EU have been gentler with the Greek people themselves? I would say yes, but then, why should my taxpayers in Scotland pay for irresponsible profligacy at the other end of the continent?  Catalonia too has shown that the EU is ultimately a club of member states and there is work to do. There&rsquos a democratic discussion that needs to be promoted between Barcelona and Madrid and the EU has not stepped up, though I hope it may yet. At least on Hungary, this week the Parliament has stood up for democracy and the rule of law.  However, in the face of this overwhelming display of what the EU can be, there were still 197 members of our European Parliament that opposed taking action against Mr Orb&aacuten. My greatest shock comes not from UKIP and the Front National, you&rsquod expect it of them, but from the UK Conservatives who were the only governing right-wing party to support him.  They voted to support the policies and the man, in the face of everything he stands for. My most charitable explanation is that this shows the chronic weakness of the UK post-Brexit as its government desperately cuddles up to anyone who might provide some help irrespective of morals or long-term strategic cost. At its worst this is a sign that the Conservative party is shting hard to the right and anything goes.  I think it is the latter and increasingly I do not think you can describe the Conservatives as a centre-right party. The clues are in the company they keep. It was because of an ill thought out commitment to appease the right in David Cameron&rsquos 2005 leadership campaign that the party left the centre-right EPP group of the parliament and set up their own. Earlier this year they invited the anti-migrant Swedish-Democrats to join them. Yes, the party that was the focus of so much concern in last weekend&rsquos Swedish election are happy members of the same Group as Mrs May&rsquos Tories.  Unfortunately, the rhetoric of our Prime Ministers also fits with that of the hard right. David Cameron talked about &ldquoswarms of migrants. In the debate this week Mr Bay of the French Front National said that &ldquothe EU promotes multiculturalism, against out values. How is that so dferent from Mrs May&rsquos &ldquo you believe you are a citizen of the world, you are a citizen of nowhere?  I fear for the Tories and for what they may turn into. I fear for what that means for the rest of us  we&rsquore stuck in a brexit Britain run by them. Right now there is a fight going on in constituency branches across the UK. This is a fight for the soul of their party and I fear the old fashioned &lsquosmall c&rsquo liberal Conservatives are losing. There are still those fighting but they are increasingly cast out or in a minority. The MEPs Richard Ashworth and Julie Girling voted against Orb&aacuten but they have already felt the need to leave the Conservative group in the Parliament. Only one actual Tory MEP voted against Orb&aacuten and I want to end by praising Nosheena Mobarik, Conservative MEP for Scotland. She not only voted with us and her conscience, she defied what I&rsquod guess was a pretty tough London imposed group whip as well. I hope her colleagues across the UK will look to her action, ask themselves some hard questions and set about challenging those who are changing the Tory party into something they find unthinkable. Their silent acquiescence has implications for all of us.

title: birthday celebration for charity knitter iris
story: A Rothienorman woman who knits items for charity is preparing to celebrate her 98th birthday.                Iris Joyce will mark her 98th year in November.                                                    The Kinbroon House resident spends most of her time knitting items for the Fish &amp Chip Babies project.                                                    The project provides hand crafted clothing to new mothers in Africa.        The ‘Fish &amp Chip Babies’ project was set up after it was discovered that newborns were wrapped in newspaper to keep them warm  no articles of clothing were available.Knitters across the UK, including Iris, decided to take action and have since knitted ious pieces of clothing to help the youngsters.Iris currently makes jumpers and matching hats for the project.She used to make booties but found them to be very time consuming.                                                                                                        Iris has made over 1,000 items for the project since she started in 2013 and each jumper and hat takes her just a day and a half to complete.She creates the items from wool given to her by her neighbour, Tina.Commenting on her neighbour’s upcoming birthday and charity achievements, Tina said: “She’s totally amazing.”Iris said: “I started knitting dishcloths but got promoted!”                                                                                                        Iris is from Romford, Essex originally, but she was sent to Raigmore, Inverness during the war to work as a copy typist.After meeting her husband, the couple moved to London, before Iris made the move north.She has lived in Rothienorman for eight years.Knitting has always been a favourite hobby of hers as Iris explained: “I am an ex-golfer, I used to do three miles on the course and I knitted my husband’s golf vests.“Now I’ve always got knitting on the go, the only time I’m not knitting is when I’m in my bed - that’s when I read.”                                                                                                        Looking to her 98th birthday, Iris said: “I have had a very happy le, I am lucky in a lot of ways and I count my blessings.“I’m young at heart.”

title: focus on rural tourism at fyvie
story: Highlighting the importance of the rural tourism economy was the focus of a seminar organised by VisitScotland recently.                Around 70 representatives from businesses in the east of Aberdeenshire attended the agri-tourism event at Fyvie Castle, where delegates had the opportunity to hear from speakers about current industry trends and network with tourism businesses locally.                                                    In Aberdeenshire, 65% of the population is based rurally – which highlights the wealth of opportunity that exists to continue to build, expand and be entrepreneurial with rural links, to continue to attract visitors to our part of Scotland. Nationally, the value of domestic visitor spend in rural areas amounts to £633 million and equates to 2.6 million domestic trips.                                                    Chris Greenwood, VisitScotland’s Senior Tourism Insights Manager, spoke to delegates about agricultural and rural tourism insights and the impacts and benefits for Aberdeenshire and Chris Foy, Chief Executive at VisitAberdeenshire presented the new destination strategy for Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire, detailing how they hope to grow visitor spend to £1 billion per year by 2023.        A new plan to develop food and drink tourism in Scotland – aiming to deliver an additional £1 billion to Scotland’s economy by 2030 – was recently launched by Nicola Sturgeon. At the event, Peter Cook, Director of Food, Drink and Agriculture at Opportunity North East, updated those attending about Opportunity North East’s work within that sector.Jo Robinson, VisitScotland Regional Director, said: “I am delighted that representatives from so many businesses in East Aberdeenshire attended this event, which hopefully gave them real food for thought on the subject of rural tourism.“This region has tremendous assets and strengths that offer visitors a range of great experiences – from food and drink to farm shops, coasts to castles and woods to wigwams. VisitScotland helps to promote these strengths to a global audience.“With 21% of domestic visitor trips being to rural areas and 22% of domestic visitor spend being in rural areas, capitalising on these visitors is so important. Hopefully events like this can help rural businesses to make the most of these opportunities.”                                                                                                        Gillian Martin, Aberdeenshire East MSP, said: “We have one of the most erse regions in Scotland with an abundance of historical and cultural signicance and interest. There is so much to do and see in rural parts and right across Aberdeenshire and we must do all we can to maximise the opportunities for tourism and economic growth by attracting new visitors to the North-east.”Chris Foy, VisitAberdeenshire Chief Executive, added: “The event reflected the importance of rural tourism for the North-east which is a signicant priority set within the destination strategy for the next five years.“It is encouraging to see the strong desire from local industry to work alongside VisitScotland and VisitAberdeenshire to strengthen the appeal of the destination to visitors, and the quality of the experience.”

title: temporary closure for post office
story: Kemnay Post Office will close temporarily from the start of next month.                The post office is located inside Kemnay Pharmacy.                                                    Speaking to the Herald, a Post Office spokesperson, said: “We have recently received a resignation notice from the Postmaster for Kemnay Post Office and the branch is due to be temporarily closed from Friday, October 5.                                                    "We would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community.        "We are seeking a new partner to take on the Post Offices, local retailers interested in this business opportunity should contact us on 0845 266 8790 or email NTquestions@postoffice.”

title: top entries to compete at thainstone show and sale
story: The Thainstone Centre will host its annual multi-breed pedigree ram show and sale later this month.                The renowned event, to be held on Tuesday, September 25, has been sponsored by Harbro and will feature 725 entries.                                                    The line-up of judges includes Brian Anderson, Shetland for the Texel section, Jonnie Campbell, Thurso for Suffolks, Neil Eddie, Montrose for Beltex, Alan Bradley, Huntly for Blue-faced Leicester, Michael Shearer, Thurso for Border Leicester, and Ryan Shand, Huntly for Charollais.                                                    Colin Slessor, Deputy Head of Livestock, said: “We have a strong entry of quality rams forward from the North and North East of Scotland for our upcoming Thainstone pedigree ram sale.        “The sale presents commercial flock masters with a unique and ideal opportunity to purchase the best rams available for their businesses, and there is always a select number of entries suitable for pedigree breeding.“We look forward to welcoming everyone to what promises to be a strong show and sale.”The event will start at 8am with the judging of Suffolk rams, followed by Blue-faced Leicester at 8.30am, Border Leicester at 9.00am, Charollais at 9.30am, Texel at10am, and all other breeds at 11am. The sale will commence at 9.30am in ring two beginning with Suffolks rams.

title: visitor centre is pride of inverurie
story: The Bennachie Visitor Centre has been crowned Tourist Hotspot of the Year at the Pride of Inverurie Awards 2018.                The event was held at Inverurie Town Hall on Friday, August 24, when the centre was announced as winner.                                                    Bennachie Centre warden, Jan Lythgoe,  received the prize on behalf of the centre, along with seasonal assistant Catherine Leaney.                                                    Jan said: “We were delighted when we heard that we were finalists in this category alongside Inverurie Gold Club and Castle Fraser.        “To be the winner is amazing - the Pride of Inverurie Awards have helped put us on the map.”The visitor centre has undergone a programme of phased improvements since 2014 and offers an indoor seating area where visitors can enjoy snacks and hot drinks.Visitor facilities have been enhanced with the creation of a Community Room, touch-screen ‘Bennachie Experience’ and a new information and retail area.This has resulted in visitor numbers increasing from 15,000 a year in 2007 to 40,000 a year in 2017. It has also been awarded four star status by VisitScotland.                                                                                                        The centre will continue to look forward and improve its facilities for new and repeat visitors, responding to changing customer needs and industry trends.The Bennachie Visitor Centre is run through a partnership agreement between Aberdeenshire Council, The Bennachie Centre Trust, Forest Enterprise Scotland and the Bailies of Bennachie.

title: Blackmail claims over mums to be
story: A WHISTLEBLOWER at Raigmore Hospital has alleged that midwives were &ldquoblackmailed into taking on patients from Elgin in order to prevent Caithness mums-to-be from travelling to Glasgow to give birth.The midwe, whose identity has been concealed on request as the person is contracted to NHS Highland, said that due to maternity services at Dr Gray&rsquos Hospital in Elgin being downgraded, expectant mums in Moray had to travel to Inverness to give birth.A large percentage of women in Caithness also have to travel to Raigmore.The additional workload from Elgin has led to anger among midwery staff who are also aggrieved that pregnant Caithness women were allegedly used as a bargaining chip.The whistle-blower said: &ldquoThe maternity services at Elgin were downgraded and that meant an influx of new patients on top of the ones we already have from Caithness.&ldquoWe made it clear to management that we were overworked as it is and a new batch of expectant mums would increase that even further.&ldquoWe asked  they could be erted to Aberdeen but we were told  we refused to take on Elgin patients then the Caithness ones would be removed from our workload.&ldquoEssentially, that meant that women would have to travel all the way from Caithness to Glasgow in order to give birth.&ldquoWe did not want that to happen and we reluctantly took on the extra workload.&ldquoThis comes at a time of year when all the Christmas surprises come into the world. September has a high rate of babies being born.&ldquoStaff morale is already at an all-time low. Several experienced midwives are either retiring or leaving because of the added workload and the burden it is causing.Bill Fernie of the pressure group Caithness Health Action Team said he was not surprised that a midwe felt compelled to speak out.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos a terrible situation for the staff to find themselves in. They should be commended for all their efforts.&ldquoTravelling to Raigmore places more than enough strain on the mums and their families so going to Glasgow would have added to that. I can fully understand why someone at Raigmore would want to whistle-blow as it appears to be a pretty fraught situation.An NHS Highland spokesman said: &ldquoDue to the unpredictable nature of maternity activity, cases are assessed on an inidual basis and robust risk assessment and escalation plans are in place to ensure safe service provision.&ldquoTo date, since accepting intrapartum transfers from Elgin, there has been no need for any Caithness woman to be erted from Raigmore Hospital to deliver elsewhere due to staffing levels or capacity, as is being suggested by the midwe whom you interviewed.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Bower author helping Norn become the norm
story: COMMON words and phrases used by Caithnessians may be thought of by locals as slang terms &ndash but, by using them, they may have been reviving a dead language.Bower author Elspeth Grace Hall is doing her bit to revive the language of Norn that was once widely spoken in Caithness.Norn was officially declared a &ldquodead language by world heritage body the United Nations Educational, Scientic and Cultural Organization .However, Grace Hall has been bringing about a revival of the region&rsquos native tongue by writing a series of children&rsquos workbooks to teach kids how to read and write in Norn.If Elspeth is successful in helping to increase the numbers of Norn speakers in Caithness, UNESCO could reverse its death declaration.They had once delivered a similar verdict on Kernowek &ndash the native language of south-west English county, Cornwall.But in 2010, UNESCO announced that its former classication of the language as &ldquoextinct was &ldquono longer accurate.Grace Hall said: &ldquoIf you have ever sat &lsquoO a benk&rsquo, fed the &lsquoscorries&rsquo, told your &lsquomannie&rsquo off for being a &lsquoloon&rsquo or simply popped off &lsquotill&rsquo the shops you have been speaking a second language &ndash one that officially doesn&rsquot even exist.&ldquoI&rsquove always been intrigued by languages and the Caithness dialect is wonderfully rich.&ldquoI started to investigate the etymology of words unique to Caithness and found that they weren&rsquot part of Scots, English or Gaelic, they were in fact Norn. A language that official bodies such as the UNESCO insist has been dead since the 1800&rsquos.&ldquoIt wouldn&rsquot be the first time UNESCO has prematurely pronounced a language as dead. Back in 2009 UNESCO declared Manx extinct despite there being over 1500 speakers of Manx.&ldquoUNESCO was forced to change its classication of Manx from &ldquoExtinct to &lsquoEndangered&rsquo after a group of school children wrote to them in Manx asking what language they were writing in  Manx didn&rsquot exist.&ldquoThe more people I talked to the more I came to find that Norn isn&rsquot dead, it has just become lost in our English. When I gave people examples they shrugged them off as &lsquoCaithness Words&rsquo but it is so much more than that it is &lsquoCaithness language&rsquo  only we put our minds and our hearts to it.With her Norn Min series workbooks Grace Hall is spreading the Norn language both within Caithness and outside of the region as well.She added: &ldquoThe Norn Min series has three workbooks published and another two in the pipeline. Copies of the series have sold as far away as America and Sweden.&ldquoIt was just after the publication of Norn Min buk two that I received an email from the University of Bari in Italy as their Minority Languages department was interested in Norn.&ldquoThey asked  they could use the Norn Min series to create an Italian-Norn phrasebook. A week later I was contacted by the World Children&rsquos Book project and they offered me a contract to translate five of their books into Norn.The World Children&rsquos Book project has over 200 translators making their bilingual books available in languages traditional publishes ignore such as English Igbo in Nigeria, German/Tigrinya in Ethiopia and now English/Norn in Scotland.Copies of both the workbooks and storybooks are available at John O&rsquoGroats and Caithness Horizons.&nbspSunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Dont miss chance to nominate a hero
story: TIME is running out to nominate someone you know to be one of this year's Highland Heroes.The awards, organised by SPP Media and now in their second year, celebrate people in the Highlands who make a real dference to our communities, healthcare, education, safety and wellbeing.Readers are being invited to nominate people in any of the 12 categories: primary pupil, secondary pupil, primary teacher, secondary teacher, carer, fundraiser, volunteer, community champion, brave child, health professional, emergency services or armed forces hero and public servant.The deadline for nominations is midnight tomorrow.SPP Media's editorial director David Bourn said: "This is a last call for you to tell us about the real heroes who go above and beyond to make your community, workplace or school a special place."Highland Heroes wants to celebrate the contribution people in our area make to the lives of others by giving them the recognition they deserve."So  you know a Highland Hero, now is the time to share their story."To nominate somebody for the awards, visit www.surveymonkey/r/HighlandHeroes2018 or email heroes@spp-group with your name, address, email and phone number, along with the person you are nominating, up to 200 words to explain why, and their contact details.After the deadline closes, a judging panel will draw up a shortlist in each category before readers are given the opportunity to vote for their favourites in a special supplement we will publish in September.The winners of each category, along with an overall hero, will be announced at a ceremony at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on Thursday, November 8.The awards are sponsored by Inverness Airport.* Click here to  about Highland Heroes.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Free sanitary products for pupils
story: SANITARY products will be made freely available to pupils and students at Caithness schools following a funding boost from the Scottish Government.A sum of &pound5.2 million will be spent across the Highlands with Caithness getting its share to provide items such as tampons and sanitary pads for learners.Following a recent VoucherCodesPro survey of over 2000 women, it was revealed that a monthly spend on sanitary products cost females &pound13 per month.This had led for calls to combat &ldquoperiod poverty to help ease the financial burden on women and female teens who may be on low incomes.Recently, Celtic football club announced it would be supplying free sanitary products in the ladies&rsquo toilets at their Parkhead stadium for female supporters to use  needed.MSP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, Gail Ross of the SNP has backed the Scottish Government&rsquos initiativeIt was extermely successful when it was trialled in Aberdeen last year.The Scottish Government has also provided the charity, FareShare, with over &pound500,000 to distribute free sanitary products to women on low incomes across Scotland.Mrs Ross said: &ldquoThe SNP Government&rsquos &pound5.2 million investment in free sanitary products will allow students in the Highlands to remain focused on what matters &ndash their studies.She underlined that &ldquobasic sanitary provision is a right, not a privilege.&ldquoThe notion that anyone should struggle to buy essential hygiene products is simply not acceptable and we should be proud that Scotland is leading the way in the fight against period poverty, Mrs Ross said.&ldquoI would encourage everyone to get firmly behind initiatives like this, including the UK government.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Gone to walk the dogs for 874 miles
story: TAKING your dog for a walk is normally a leisurely pastime for some but animal rights activist Robert Donkers has taken it to a new level &ndash an 874 mile one.The 55-year-old, who lives in north London but originally hails from Indonesia, is on a walk from Lands End to John O&rsquoGroats accompanied by his three shih tzus  and chihuahua .Donkers, who is also an animal healer and massage therapist, is doing the walk to raise awareness and funds to help end &ldquothe barbaric dog-meat trade in south-east Asia.Festivals such as Yulin, celebrate the torture and consumption of dogs.It is thought that inflicting pain such as blow torching, bludgeoning and skinning and boiling them alive, makes their flesh taste more tender, and helps those who eat it cope with hot weather.However, dog-eating festivals represent less than 0.01 per cent of the dog-meat trade as a whole. In China, more than 10 million dogs are killed and eaten every year.Robert, who will have reached Inverness by the time you have picked up your copy of the Groat, said: &ldquoI started campaigning against the dog-meat trade in the far east after seeing a YouTube clip showing the terrible cruelty inflicted on the dogs destined to be eaten.&ldquoAs a child in Indonesia, I would hear about family pets being sold or stolen for meat.&ldquoNow I aim to do all that I can to save dogs from that horrible fate. My organisation, Walking to Save Dogs, raises funds to support carefully selected local shelters and projects that rescue dogs from these Festivals and the meat trade.&ldquoThe ultimate goal is to put an end to the dog-meat trade through education that dogs are sentient beings, changing legislation, and providing dog-meat traders with alternative means to support their families.Robert aims to reach John O&rsquoGroats by September 18, although he has already lost one of his canine companions.He added: &ldquoSadly, Madeleine recently developed an eye problem so has gracefully pawed out.&ldquoShe continues to support the rest of the pack from a comfy armchair at home.&ldquoMy pets are the voice of millions of less fortunate dogs.&ldquoThey have been well-prepared for this task and they love the outdoors.&ldquoWe have been walking 12 miles a day on average and hope to finish our walk within a couple of weeks.&ldquoI am touched beyond words at the kindness and generosity of the Scottish people I have met along the trail and look forward to meeting lots more on the way to John O&rsquoGroats.To follow Robert&rsquos progress and to donate, go to: www.walkingtosavedogs or www.justgiving/crowdfunding/walkingtosavedogsSunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: High success rate for Wick school leavers
story: WICK High has been praised for how they prepare their pupils for the adult world once they leave school.A report from the director of education, presented by Alison Donald, education quality improvement manager for the north, showed that leavers from the school had made considerable progress with a large number going onto positive destinations.These include universities, higher education colleges and full-time employment.The breakdown of positive destinations showed that54.4 per cent of pupils going on to higher and further Edu-cation in 2014/15 had now increased over two years to 60.6 per cent.On top of that, nearly10 per cent of pupils becoming unemployed either seeking or not seeking employment in 2014/15 had fallen to less than one per cent in 2016/17.Local councillors have welcomed the report&rsquos findings and have praised the school for helping pupils embark on a positive course when they leave.Councillor Raymond Bremner said: &ldquoIt is absolutely fantastic to see that in two years of performance analysis in respect of pupils going on to positive destinations from Wick High School.&ldquoThis surely has to be one of the best improvement increases in the Highlands,  not the country and you cannot help but be extremely proud of this on behalf of the school.&ldquoThe figures detailing the types of destination our pupils from Wick High School are going to are also hugely encouraging. Our local pupils going on to higher and further education has increased by over six per cent and this is now ahead of the Highland average.&ldquoWe can also see, even though we remain behind the Scotland figure for higher and further education by a margin of about five per cent, this is more than offset by the fact that more than 31 per cent of pupils go directly into employment, nearly 10 per cent ahead of the country&rsquos average and equal to the Highland average.&ldquoIn terms of paving a more positive path for our youngsters&rsquo future, this is a real good news story and I&rsquom hugely delighted for everyone involved at Wick High School.Councillor Nicola Sinclair echoed Cllr Bremner&rsquos comments by adding: &ldquoWhat an achievement this is and we should be ensuring that the appreciation of all the hard work is acknowledged across the board from the head teacher, to the management team, to all the teachers and pupils &ndash this reflects a huge effort from everyone involved in the school and the local community.&nbspSunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Jobs boost for AMTE Power in Thurso
story: THE number of staff at a Thurso business is to increase by 25 per cent over the next year following a partnership deal with a British technology company.The workforce at AMTE Power Ltd, based at Thurso Business Park, is expected to rise from 32 to 40 following the deal with QinetiQ whose headquarters are in Farnborough in Hampshire. QinetiQ employs 6000 staff and has a turnover of around &pound700 million.The deal comes as AMTE Power has invested &pound1.5 million in a new automated production line at its Caithness operation.John Fox, the company&rsquos marketing director, yesterday described the partnership agreement as &ldquoa positive step for AMTE Power and the local economy.He explained the two business will work together to develop battery cells.&ldquoWe will use our manufacturing expertise to utilise QinetiQ&rsquos experience in battery technology and research to deliver new products, manufactured in Thurso to an international customer base, Mr Fox said.He said the companies will concentrate on four key areas: defence, the oil and gas industry, energy storage and electric vehicles. They plan to supply UK and European markets with niche batteries which customers would not be able to get elsewhere.Mr Fox said there is potential and opportunities in these areas and the increase in the Thurso workforce will be largely due to the link-up with QinetiQ.The partnership deal, he stressed, will allow customers to get products which &ldquodon&rsquot rely on standard mass-produced cells from the existing supply chain.The agreement will enable the companies to develop &ldquoa mutually beneficial relationship and lead to advances in batteries and energy storage products.&ldquoOur staff in Thurso are fantastic and we will continue to grow our base there, he said. &ldquoWe have 32 employees in Caithness at present but have plans for that figure to go up to 40 over the next year &ndash that is a 25 per cent increase.&ldquoThis is a great building block for the future development of the organisation. We have had great support from the community and are committed to Thurso and Caithness.Kevin Brundish, chief executive of AMTE Power, said: &ldquoThe combination of world-leading British innovation from QinetiQ coupled with the manufacturing capability of AMTE allows customers access to new and exciting energy storage options, giving them a choice beyond the existing supply chain.&ldquoThe new products will see step change in capability and alternative options for our technology customers.Mike Sewart of QinetiQ said: &ldquoWe recognise that our strengths lie in research, prototyping and scale-up of cutting-edge battery technology and not in large-scale manufacturing. This partnership will help us to take our technology to a broader customer base and provides us with the manufacturing support and expertise we need.AMTE is a privately owned company and is the UK&rsquos only volume cell manufacturing facility.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: MP Stone lashes out at raving bonkers boundary change
story: LOCAL politicians Jamie Stone and Gail Ross have united to condemn UK Government proposals to extend the boundaries of the Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross constituency.The measures could see the name of Caithness being consigned to history in terms of Westminster representation  the expanded seat becomes known as Highland North.Mr Stone condemned the idea of a larger constituency as &ldquostark raving bonkers.The Boundary Commission for Scotland has released a report that recommends the number of UK seats in Scotland should be cut from 59 to 53. Westminster itself would see its total number of MPs cut from 650 to 600.One ramication includes the expansion of the Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross seat, which has Mr Stone of the Liberal Democrats as its sitting MP, to include a part of Lochaber.Mr Stone said: &ldquoThese changes would make our constituency a monster in terms of size.&ldquoPeople have a right of access to their local MP but that representative can only do so much and only drive so many miles to serve the electorate.&ldquoThe journey from Evanton in the south-east to John O&rsquoGroats is 103 miles. It takes two hours and 49 minutes to drive the 115 miles from Lochinver in the south-west to Wick in the north-east.&ldquoMy constituency covers 3675 square miles. We could fit all 73 London constituencies in my constituency, and have room left over around the sides.&ldquoThe proposed changes are simply an example of the Boundary Commission running mad and it undermines democracy.&ldquoWith the best will in the world, it is very hard to cover the communities within my constituency, even when driving hither and thither.&ldquoThe point is that constituencies and communities have a right of access to their elected member.&ldquoDespite doing what I hope is my best,  there is a shortfall in what I can do in terms of reaching out, why would I not suggest that there is a slight democratic deficit?&ldquoWhen an idea is stark raving bonkers, like this one, it just has to be said loud and clear.&ldquoI will, of course, contest the seat at the next election. I may not hold the seat, as I may be voted out, but whoever represents the seat will have a very dficult time representing those good people  the constituency gets any bigger.SNP MSP Gail Ross, who holds the Holyrood seat of Caithness, Sutherland and Ross, stated that the proposed changes were unacceptable even though they could in theory help her party to win Mr Stone&rsquos seat.&ldquoThat will be up to the electorate but I would rather we win a seat by having a good candidate and policies that appeal to voters than because the seat has been given extra territory, she said.&ldquoI share Jamie&rsquos concerns as my own ward for Holyrood is a massive challenge for me to get around it.&ldquoDespite all the technology in place, such as Skype and WhatsApp, you need to visit all the parts of your constituency to see what is going on and to properly speak with constituents face to face.&ldquoI have colleagues who hold seats in urban areas who are shocked by the amount of travelling I have to do to meet and listen to constituents.&ldquoWe need more representation and smaller wards so that the electorate can be properly served by their MP and MSP.&ldquoAs for the proposed name change of the Westminster seat to &lsquoHighland North&rsquo, that will see Caithness taken off the political map.&ldquoIt will also be name that&rsquos misleading as to how big the constituency is. I&rsquom often referred to by some media outlets as a &lsquofar north MSP&rsquo which doesn&rsquot give any indication of how wide a range the electorate in my own ward is.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: New group set up to save Trinkie
story: MEMORIES of the golden era of the Trinkie came flooding back this week when a new group was set up with the intention of restoring Wick&rsquos famous outdoor pool to its former glory.From the reflections, you&rsquod think people were talking of the sun-swept coast of Spain, or &ndash more closely &ndash the holiday camp pools of Butlin&rsquos or the 1980s TV show Hi-de-Hi.A signicant number of Wick residents turned up to the meeting at the Francis Street Club, where it was decided to form the Trinkie Heritage Preservation Group.A previous group was disbanded earlier this year, blaming a &ldquolack of community support.Friends of the Trinkie said it had enjoyed maintaining the outdoor pool at Wick&rsquos South Head over the years, and stressed that it had not been an easy decision.For years, the lido on the Pulteneytown seafront formed a communal gathering spot, not just where people learned to swim, but also for barbecues, get-togethers and family occasions. Local resident and self-professed &ldquoTrinkie lover Bryan Newlands welcomed the group&rsquos formation, underlining that the pool harboured a lot of memories. &ldquoI used to go there a lot... Even though I lived on the other side of town, every summer myself and a friend would go &ndash even when it was raining, he said. &ldquoIt was a great place as the town didn&rsquot have an indoor swimming pool until 1994. Many people learned to swim at the Trinkie.While a slideshow showed images of how the pool used to look and how much Wickers got from it, other more contemporary images show a dilapidated ruin &ndash a far cry from the hustle, bustle and smiles of yesteryear.The new group was formed with a mission to &ldquobring the pool back to le and a number of office-bearers were proposed and elected.James Bremner was elected chairman with other roles going to William Macdonald , Catherine Patterson  and Garance Warburton .Seven committee members were also elected: Fiona Bremner, Trudi Mcalpine, Davina Lyall, Fiona McPhee, Leslie Grant, Roddy Mackay and Councillor Willie Mackay.Ms Patterson underlined that it was going to be no easy fix as &ldquothere are holes in the wall at the deep end, which also has cracks that go right down to the ground.&ldquoThe previous group... had the holes patched up, but they kept reappearing, she said. &ldquoThe wall itself is also crumbling and the bridge that ides the deep and shallow ends has had its fixtures corroded. Also the south access road that leads the public to the pool is in poor nick.She stressed that volunteers to patch things up and general goodwill is always welcome, &ldquobut [often] their help only scratches the surface of what needs to be done.She added: &ldquoMajor investment is needed along with a report from a structural engineer to see how much damage there is, what can and cannot be done, and to get an estimate of how much the restoration will cost.Mr Newlands &ndash committee member Ms Lyall&rsquos son &ndash stressed that the Trinkie added tremendous character to Wick.&ldquoPut it this way, with the summer we&rsquove had, that pool would have been full had it been in use, he said.Other memories came from Wick Society chairman Iain Leith. &ldquoGoing there was a popular pastime in its day with adults and kids from all over Pulteneytown flocking to it, he said.&ldquoRestoring it could be a big boost to the town&rsquos economy by making it a tourist attraction as well as giving back the town a much-loved landmark.Ms Patterson emphasised that the Trinkie had the potential to be an asset to both locals and tourists.&ldquoBut we need investment because  nothing gets done the pool is on its way out.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:39 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: New service gives job hunters a Fair Start
story: &nbspScottish Government ViewpointFAIR Start Scotland is the country's new devolved employment support service.It is focused on supporting unemployed people who have challenges in accessing the labour market for whom work is a realistic prospect.Launched in April, earlier this year, it is an example of one of the first uses of newly devolved powers under the 2016 Scotland Act.The service will run until 2023 and aims to provide tailored, flexible and person-centred support to at least 38,000 people across Scotland who want help to find work, and stay in work.Fair Start Scotland is distinctive in that participation is purely voluntary.This means that people have everything to gain and nothing to lose &ndash choosing to participate will not affect existing benefits or be driven by fear of benefit sanctions.The service is delivered locally, meaning that no participants are left without the support they need.Delivery is over nine geographic areas including the Highlands and reflects local area economies, meeting the needs of employers, disabled people and those at risk of long-term unemployment.Jamie Hepburn, Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills, said: "What's crucial about Fair Start Scotland is that it treats people with fairness, dignity and respect and that it is focused on the needs of the inidual."We are dedicated to delivering a high quality employment support service that will lead to real and sustained job outcomes and help people to achieve their full potential."As well as meeting the needs of unemployed people, Fair Start Scotland also seeks to help businesses find the skilled and committed employees they need to thrive."One of the many now benefitting is Highlander Alan Cairns .He has not worked for over a year and his biggest barriers to work have been low confidence and computer skills but now he has secured 16 hours of work per week.Alan started on the Fair Start Scotland service in the middle of May and has been attending the service for the past 12 weeks. He can now use Microsoft Outlook and completed his new CV on Microsoft Word and been applying online for jobs.Alan said: "I've attended workshops on confidence building, and digital skills."My confidence is improving a lot and so is my computer skills, I have been job searching online and sending emails, I couldn't do this before."* To find out more and check eligibility for the service visit www.mygov.scot/fairstartSunday 16 Sep 2018 1:39 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Norse era in Caithness was our very own Game of Thrones
story: He has taken some of the most dramatic events from a time when the county was the southern part of the Orkney earldom and condensed them into a rollicking, fast-moving narrative in The Katanes Saga .It is based on a series of articles published in the John O&rsquoGroat Journal over a decade ago, reinterpreting source material from ious sagas, and follows on from The Raven Banner, published in the mid-1990s and now out of print. Like that earlier work, The Katanes Saga is told in an unpretentious, engaging, sometimes blokey style. From the drunken arguments to the devious plots to the mutilations and killings, Cassells tells it like it is.&ldquoThe Raven Banner was basically a guide to Norse Caithness with a little bit about each area and what I thought were the main things that happened in Norse times, he explains. &ldquoThe Katanes Saga is far more in-depth.&ldquoThey were people like you and me. They had the same faults. You could meet three Vikings in the pub any night.&ldquoOne word I would use to describe the Norse is pragmatic. They were really pragmatic people. If that&rsquos the way it works, that&rsquos the way it works &ndash  it doesn&rsquot, I&rsquoll do it my way.&ldquoI do mention that of all the Norse earls of Orkney only a handful actually died in their beds. Most suffered violent deaths. One was killed with contact poison from his own auntie and mother on a shirt.Cassells  is a retired Royal Mail manager who previously worked as a lighthouse keeper on Muckle Flugga and Stroma. Those experiences inspired two other books, No More Paraffin-Oilers and A Light Walk.The Katanes Saga sees him ing to a theme that first sparked his interest at an early age. Born in Barrow, he moved to Thurso in late 1950s when his father came to work at the Admiralty test establishment.&ldquoI always liked Greek and Roman mythology and I started reading about Norse mythology as well, he recalls. &ldquoAs a young boy I lived in Sweyn Road in Thurso and I wondered who Sweyn was. A pal of mine said, &lsquoAch, that&rsquoll be Sweyn the pirate.&rsquo So for about a year I had this happy vision of a Pugwash-type character that the street was named after. I then discovered Sweyn Aslearson.Swyen , iously described &ldquothe last of the Vikings and &ldquothe greatest troublemaker in the westernlands, had an estate at Duncansby and was renowned for raiding, plundering and pillaging. One of the many who suffered at his hands was Frakokk, who had featured in the poisoned-shirt incident: she was burned to death in her farmhouse at Helmsdale, along with other members of her faction, in a revenge attack led by Swyen.It&rsquos an example of the way in which many of the strands are intertwined, as Cassells points out.&ldquoI read the sagas and I started taking a look at place names, he says. &ldquoFor a long time I lived at Scrabster &ndash Skarabolstadr, the &lsquohomestead of the sea-mews&rsquo.&ldquoAnd the stories were interesting to read. They were intriguing.&ldquoYou try and unravel it and it&rsquos just more or less two families feuding all the way through it. That goes right to the very last act of the local earl being kned in a beer cellar in Thurso.One of the most shocking events is the burning to death of Bishop Adam by a mob in Halkirk in a dispute over a butter tax.&ldquoHe got a bit greedy, Cassells says. &ldquoThey complained to the earl at the time who more or less said, &lsquoDamn the bishop, you can burn him as you please,&rsquo so they took him at his word.&ldquoBishops crop up a couple of times. There was lot of enmity between the local Norse earldom and the Scottish king over bishops. A bishop got his eyes put out in Scrabster.&ldquoAfter the bishop was murdered at Halkirk, the Scottish king came up here and carried out what was, for want of a better description, pure genocide of the people from the Halkirk area. I believe they were all massacred round about where the Pennyland estate is now in Thurso. Hundreds of people were killed there.&ldquoIn those days you just didn&rsquot go burning bishops &ndash they&rsquore going to come down heavy on you.&ldquoRavenshill Road used to be known as the Gallows Hill, before the atomic houses were built there, so that has been a place for judicial executions for quite a long time.From the machinations of the &ldquofemme fatale Ragnhild at Murkle to the murder of Earl Rognvald at Forsie to the Battle of Clairdon Hill outside Thurso, the power struggles and manoeuvrings come thick and fast. It&rsquos a rapid-fire history lesson, but more than anything Cassells simply wants people to enjoy the stories.&ldquoIt&rsquos a thing I never learned in school here. It was never mentioned, he says. &ldquoThis is our own local history, and I just hope people think it&rsquos a good read.The Katanes Saga  is self-published and is on sale in Caithness Horizons, newsagents in Thurso, and Wick Heritage Museum.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:39 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Open evening in Thurso for potential Childrens Panel members
story: AN open evening is taking place next week with the aim of attracting volunteers for the Children&rsquos Panel in Caithness.Tuesday&rsquos event in Thurso will allow members of the public to find out how they can play a part in the children&rsquos hearings system &ndash helping others and giving something back to the community in the process.Volunteers from all walks of le make le-changing decisions that create a dference in the lives of many, and this is very true for children, young people and families in Caithness and across Scotland within the children&rsquos hearing system.It relies on the voluntary involvement of around 2500 people who are willing and able to give their time and commitment to serve as Children&rsquos Panel members.A number of agencies work together with the system to deliver protection, care and support to families, children and young people. These include social work, police, education, the Scottish Children&rsquos Reporter Administration and Children&rsquos Hearings Scotland.No new panel member begins sitting on hearings without a thorough training being delivered beforehand. For any new Caithness trainees, the training takes place in Inverness.Panel member and trainer Christine Stone said: &ldquoIt has been a great privilege to serve as a volunteer on the Children&rsquos Panel for over 18 years and there are others residing within Caithness who have served for more than 20 years. Caithness Children&rsquos Panel volunteers come from a wide iety of backgrounds and experiences &ndash all walks of le make for a good blend.&ldquoThe panel is always in need of new volunteers and, to that end, we are inviting any interested persons to our open evening, to take place at 7pm at the Children&rsquos Panel Office, 23 Swanson Street, Thurso, on Tuesday, August 28. Please do consider coming along!&ldquoThis is an information evening, where an overview of the voluntary work will be given, which will be followed by a question-and-answer session.&ldquoThis is a great opportunity to find out more and to see  this is for you. Being a panel member is hugely rewarding &ndash it is a great privilege to be able to come alongside families, young people and children in crisis and help them move forward constructively to a better future.&ldquoIf you are interested in applying to become a panel member, please feel free to contact me for any further information. Also, you can check out the Children&rsquos Panel website where you will find more information which should help you decide  volunteering for the Children&rsquos Panel is really for you.Sunday 16 Sep 2018 1:39 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Students get on their bikes in memory of friend
story: THREE students got on their bikes at John O&rsquoGroats earlier this week and pointed their compasses to Land&rsquos End in a bid to raise awareness about mental health.Fenn Newsome, Giles Themans and Alex Hayton decided upon the marathon pedal following the death of their friend and fellow Newcastle University student, Marcus Colville.Marcus, from Exeter, had tragically taken his own le last December. He was a third-year medical student who played rugby with the cycling trio and was also a talented musician. He had also been suffering from depression.The idea of cycling from John O&rsquoGroats to Land&rsquos End came to the trio after they had learned that Marcus had previously done the y cycle, not once but twice.Fenn, a final-year maths student from Sheffield, said that Marcus&rsquos sudden death was a huge shock to us all at the rugby club,and for everyone that knew him.&ldquoHearing the news that he had been suffering from depression was a surprise to all his friends and family, he said.&ldquoIn light of this, Marcus&rsquos family have set up a fund in his name &ndash Marcus in Mind &ndash to raise awareness and prevent this sort of tragedy happening to more young men.Giles, a marine and offshore engineering student from Bridgnorth, Shropshire, added: &ldquoThe three of us felt compelled to do something to help raise awareness of depression and mental health.&ldquoAfter learning at his funeral that Marcus had completed this very cycle ride twice, we knew it would be an appropriate challenge.&ldquoWe are using the social media hashtag #ItsOkNotToBeOk and we&rsquore hoping to remove some of the stigma and get blokes like us opening up about mental health.Given Marcus&rsquos and the trio&rsquos links with rugby, clubs around the UK have been aware of the mental health awareness drive that they&rsquore undertaking,Alex, a marine engineering student from Porthlevan, Cornwall, said: &ldquoWe have been in touch with rugby clubs up and down the country. Our aim is to spread our message far and wide and hope others may cycle with us.&ldquoWhen we discovered depression leading to suicide was the cause of Marcus&rsquos death, we couldn&rsquot believe it. We had always seen Marcus as he was at rugby &ndash a strong, witty and kind gentleman. After talking with more team-mates who have opened up and described their own experiences the horrying statistics become relatable.The cycling trio hope to be arriving at Land&rsquos End in a fortnight&rsquos time and are hoping to raise &pound2000 for the Marcus in Mind fundraiser set up by his family.To make a donation, visit the website on: justgiving/crowdfunding/for-marcusSunday 16 Sep 2018 1:39 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: hockey stars set to begin district cup defence during weekends sport
story: Orkney&#8217s senior hockey stars are set to begin their defence of the Scottish Women&#8217s District Cup this Sunday, as Orkney looks ahead to another busy weekend of sport.Just four months on from celebrating their fourth District Cup success, beating Edinburgh University Ladies 4s 4-0, Orkney  to action in Inverness on Sunday.Facing Milne Craig Clydesdale Western Ladies 4s is a tough start for the defending champions, with the Glasgow side being the last team to beat Orkney in 2016.The match is set for a 12.30pm start at Inverness&#8217s Bught Park, with supporters encouraged to come along and back Orkney.The county&#8217s footballers have a week off, but the county&#8217s men&#8217s rugby side  to home action against old rivals Caithness.The 91st meeting between the two sides — and first since 2015 — will see both sides gunning for their first victories of the season.Orkney are two bonus points clear of Caithness near the bottom of the Tennent&#8217s BT National League Division 3.Captain Scott Rendall continues to miss out with injury, but the side do welcome back Philip Ross, Chris Guthrie and Robbie Firth to the first 15.Kick-off is at 1pm at Picky.Also on Saturday, the club&#8217s Under-14 and Under-16 senior sides are due to travel away to Invergordon to take on Stornoway, with kick-off between 12 and 12.30pn depending on travel times.In swimming, more than 30 swimmers are due to travel across the Firth this weekend for the 40th annual Thurso Open Meet, while in equestrian, a dressage league will take place this Sunday.There is also a final call for entries for The Orcadian Peedie HOYS, with entries to be submitted by 5pm today .In youth football, there is plenty on over the weekend.The R. Clouston Under-12 will also take place this Saturday at Picky from 10am until 4pm.Fourteen teams from six local clubs — Rovers, East United, Stromness, Dounby, Wanderers and Hotspurs — are expected to take part in the tournament.Presentations of the cup, plate and medals is scheduled to take place after the final game around 4.10pm.The inter-county Under-14 &#8216A&#8217 and &#8216B&#8217 sides are also in action on Saturday, taking on Shetland in the second-leg of their respective ties.The matches, at Picky outfield, are set to kick-off at 12 noon for the &#8216A&#8217 sides and the &#8216B&#8217 match beginning at 1.30pm.&copy The Orcadian - 2018A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney voices heard on young brexit panel
story: Two local young people have been selected to sit on a national panel designed to ensure young peoples&#8217 voices are heard as part of the ongoing Brexit negotiations.Hope Laing and Jack Norquoy are among 20 young people from across Scotland chosen for the Children and Young People&#8217s Panel on Europe.Hope Laing is a pupil at Stromness Academy and is in the process of doing her Gold Youth Achievement and is a Young Ambassador for Year of the Young People.Jack Norquoy is one of Orkney’s two members of the Scottish Youth Parliament.As part of this landmark participation project, children and young people will have the opportunity to advise the Scottish Government on the issues they would like to be considered in Brexit negotiations with Westminster.The project has been initiated by the charity Children in Scotland and will be independently led by the charity in partnership with Together  resources to provide helpful information for children across Scotland about what leaving the EU might mean for their lives, will also be developed as part of the project.The panel will meet four times between now and December.Hope said: “I am so excited about being chosen to be on this panel as I love public speaking and supporting young people’s voices. Without the support of the Youth Achievement Group I would never have had the confidence to apply for such an important opportunity.”Maureen Herdman  said: “We are delighted for Hope as this is a great opportunity for her to further advance her skills and confidence and represent young people on a national stage. It has been a delight to watch Hope develop into a self-assured and confident young lady who is always keen to represent the views and opinions of young people from Orkney and beyond!”Jack Norquoy said: &#8220I&#8217m absolutely delighted to be part of the panel to represent the work of SYP, young folk in Orkney, and crucially help to ensure we see a progression, not a regression of young people&#8217s rights in Brexit. I&#8217m looking forward to working with everyone on the panel to influence the Brexit process constructively. Our generation will inherit the full consequences of Brexit and I believe it is only right we have our voice heard.&#8221&copy The Orcadian - 2018A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
